column2: What was the 'English musical Renaissance'?
column3: The period in which England freed themselves from foreign musical influences, to have begun writing in a distinctively national manner
column4: The period in which England freed themselves from old national English music and changed their style.
column5: The period in which English composers competed against BTS as to who could write better songs, and BTS won.
column6: The period in which England was overwhelmed by foreign musical influences and lost their national musical style.

column2: Who wrote the art song set work?
What is the rhyme scheme of each sextain in Let Us Garlands Bring?
How are the modulations in the piece used to reflect the ideas in the text?
column3: The piece is bouncy as the poet addresses the object of his affection, and becomes more reflective as the poet addresses the need to be joyful while still young.
column4: The song is determined as the idea of surviving one more day is expressed, and is temporarily taken back a notch as though building up energy to explode.
column5: The piece is more reflective as the poet addresses the object of his affection, and becomes bouncy as the poet addresses the need to be joyful while still young.
column6: The piece is slow and melancholy as the poet addresses the once-was object of his affection, and becomes reflective as he addresses the need to be joyful while still young.

column4: Melismatic and has a rhythm not very close to the declamation of the words.

column2: How does Finzi emphasise the point of the text?

column6: By using direct imitation between the voice and the piano at the first line of each stanza

column2: Describe the texture of the accompaniment at the end of the each stanza.
column3: Legato articulation and longer note values, slower pace, and dramatic contrast of dynamics.
column4: Staccato articulation and shorter note values, faster pace, no contrast of dynamics.
column5: Legato articulation and longer note values, slower pace, less contrast of dynamics.
column6: Legato articulation and shorter note values, slower pace and dramatic contrast of dynamics.

column2: Describe the cadence at the end of each stanza?
column3: It is joined with the commencement of the next piano section (interlude/postlude)
column4: It is separated from the next piano section (interlude/postlude)
column5: It is joined with the commencement of the next stanza
column6: It is joined with a four-bar outro of sorts before the interlude/postlude commences

column2: In what way is the piece flexible and natural?
column3: The voice sets the text differently in each stanza while the accompaniment stays the same.
column4: The accompaniment is different in each stanza while the voice stays the same.
column5: The voice sets the text differently in each stanza, just like the accompaniment.
column6: The voice and accompaniment stay the same, but rubato and ornaments are used.

column2: Generally, what is the role of the Piano in Art songs?
column3: Shares prominence with the vocal part
